title: 109_hr5142
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Foundation Scholars Program Act" and includes a scholarship program. The Director will establish a scholarship program for students in STEM programs at US institutions of higher education. The application process includes providing information to applicants, a deadline of January 1st, and selection of recipients by April 15th. The Director will notify scholarship recipients by April 15 through email, telephone, or mail. Scholarships are awarded based on merit, class rank, personal essay, letters of recommendation, financial need, and support for underrepresented groups. The scholarship amount is determined by the Director. The scholarship award covers tuition, room and board, and fees up to $20,000 per year. Students can't receive scholarships for more than 5 years. Failure to maintain academic achievement results in scholarship termination. Scholarships are distributed across states. The scholarship award covers tuition, room and board, and fees up to $20,000 per year for students in the States, including commonwealths, territories, and possessions of the United States, based on their congressional delegations. The Director will award $5,000 grants to universities with 10 or more scholarship recipients to develop programs including monthly speaker sessions, annual poster presentations, outreach to middle and high school students, and mentoring for recipients. The Director of the National Science Foundation is responsible for reporting to Congress on program status, scholarship recipient data, geographic distribution of awards, post-degree activities, program changes, and responding to inquiries. They are also required to establish a website for scholarship recipients to engage in various activities and research opportunities. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations for the National Science Foundation under this Act includes $242 million for 2007, $726 million for 2008, $1.695 billion for 2009, $2.18 billion for 2010, and $2.664 billion for 2011. Definitions in the Act include the Director of the NSF and the meaning of "institution of higher education."
